title: The Balfour Declaration
description:
Issued on November 2, 1917, the Balfour Declaration marked a turning point for Palestinians. In this public letter, British Foreign Secretary Arthur James Balfour pledged support for “a national home for the Jewish people” in Palestine—without consulting the indigenous Arab majority, who made up over 90% of the population.

While the declaration vaguely promised not to prejudice the rights of non-Jewish communities, the British mandate was structured in a way that enabled and empowered Jewish immigration and political self-rule, while marginalizing Palestinian Arabs. It is widely viewed as a catalyst for the 1948 Nakba and the ongoing Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: The UN Partition Plan (Resolution 181)
description:
In 1947, facing mounting tensions and pressure to withdraw from Palestine, Britain referred the issue to the United Nations. The UN formed a committee (UNSCOP) to find a solution. The majority recommendation was to divide Palestine into two independent states: one Jewish and one Arab, with Jerusalem placed under international governance.

The Jewish community supported this plan, seeing it as a legal foundation for the state of Israel. In contrast, the Arab population—and surrounding Arab nations—rejected it entirely, asserting that it violated the rights of the native majority.

On November 29, 1947, the UN General Assembly passed Resolution 181 with 33 votes in favor, 13 against, and 10 abstentions. Despite international approval, the plan immediately sparked violence and deepened the division on the ground. It’s widely seen as the precursor to the 1948 Arab-Israeli war and the Nakba.

title: The Nakba (“Catastrophe”)
description:
The Nakba refers to the mass displacement of Palestinians during the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, when over 750,000 people were forcibly expelled from their homes. Palestine—once a diverse, multicultural society—was fragmented. Villages were destroyed, families were separated, and an entire nation was uprooted.

Following the UN partition plan, Zionist militias launched attacks that drove Palestinians from their towns and villages. As the British mandate ended and Israel declared independence, war erupted across the region. The result was the permanent dispossession of more than half the Palestinian population.

Today, over 5 million Palestinian refugees remain displaced across the Middle East. The Nakba is not just a historical event—it is an ongoing experience of occupation, erasure, and denial of basic rights.

title: The Naksa (“Setback” - 1967)
description:
The Naksa, meaning “setback” in Arabic, refers to the aftermath of the 1967 Six-Day War, when Israel launched a preemptive strike against Egypt, Jordan, and Syria. In just six days, Israel captured the West Bank, Gaza Strip, East Jerusalem, the Golan Heights, and the Sinai Peninsula.

Over 300,000 more Palestinians were displaced, many of them for the second time since the Nakba of 1948. The war marked the start of Israel’s ongoing military occupation of the West Bank and Gaza, which continues today.

Israel also annexed East Jerusalem, a move unrecognized by most of the international community.

The Naksa entrenched the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and deepened the refugee crisis. It also led to the rise of Palestinian political resistance movements, including the PLO, and set the stage for future uprisings such as the First Intifada.

title: The First Intifada (1987–1993)
description:
The First Intifada was a grassroots uprising that began on December 8, 1987, after an Israeli military vehicle collided with a civilian car in Gaza, killing four Palestinians. What followed was a mass rebellion across the occupied territories, especially in Gaza and the West Bank, fueled by two decades of Israeli occupation, economic hardship, and settlement expansion.

Palestinians—especially youth—rose up using stones, strikes, graffiti, and protests. Israel responded with harsh crackdowns, including the use of live ammunition, curfews, mass arrests, and beatings. The UN Security Council condemned Israel’s excessive force. Over six years, more than 1,000 Palestinians and over 100 Israelis were killed.

The uprising ended with the 1993 Oslo Accords. The PLO recognized Israel, and Israel accepted the PLO as the representative of the Palestinian people. However, many—including groups like Hamas and figures such as Edward Said—viewed the agreement as a betrayal of Palestinian rights, especially the right of return and the liberation of all historic Palestine.

title: The Oslo Accords (1993–1995)
description:
The Oslo Accords were a series of landmark agreements between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO), beginning with Oslo I signed on September 13, 1993. It marked the first time both sides officially recognized each other and pledged to end decades of conflict.

Brokered in secret in Norway and announced in Washington, D.C., the accords led to the iconic handshake between Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and PLO leader Yasser Arafat, under the auspices of U.S. President Bill Clinton. Oslo II followed in 1995, laying out detailed plans for self-governance and dividing the West Bank into Areas A, B, and C.

However, the hope quickly faded. Israel continued building illegal settlements, while military occupation persisted. Rabin was assassinated in 1995 by a far-right Israeli opposed to the accords. Final status negotiations stalled indefinitely, and the creation of a sovereign Palestinian state never materialized.

Many Palestinians now see the accords as a cover for further dispossession, with Israel using the peace process to entrench control over Palestinian land. Prominent critics, including Edward Said, warned early on that the deal represented capitulation, not justice.

title: The Second Intifada (Al-Aqsa Intifada)
description:
The Second Intifada, also known as the Al-Aqsa Intifada, erupted on{" "} September 28, 2000, after Israeli opposition leader Ariel Sharon entered the al-Aqsa Mosque compound in occupied East Jerusalem, accompanied by over 1,000 armed forces. The visit came at a time of deep Palestinian frustration over stalled peace talks, settlement expansion, and Israel’s failure to meet the terms of the Oslo Accords.

The uprising began with mass demonstrations, largely non-violent, but was met with excessive Israeli force. Within the first few days, Israel fired over 1.3 million bullets, killing 47 Palestinians—most of them civilians—and wounding nearly 2,000. The violent suppression militarized the uprising and led to years of bloody confrontation.

Over the course of five years, at least 4,973 Palestinians were killed, including 1,262 children, and thousands more were injured. More than 5,000 Palestinian homes were demolished, and countless others displaced. Despite the popular portrayal of violence, much of the Intifada included non-violent resistance, civil disobedience, and mass mobilization, which was largely ignored by Western media.

The Second Intifada marked a significant shift in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. It deepened occupation structures, hardened Israeli policies, and was later used to justify the building of the separation wall, expansion of settlements, and entrenchment of military control over Palestinian territories.

title: Hamas Wins Majority in 2006 Elections
description:
On January 26, 2006, Hamas won a stunning victory in the Palestinian parliamentary elections, securing 76 out of 132 seats and ending the long-standing dominance of the Fatah movement. The election was widely seen as a rejection of Fatah's years of corruption, inefficiency, and failure to achieve tangible results in peace negotiations with Israel.

The result triggered the resignation of Prime Minister Ahmed Qureia and his cabinet, even before final results were confirmed. President Mahmoud Abbas remained in office, but with Hamas now controlling the legislature, the dynamics of Palestinian politics shifted dramatically.

Despite concerns from the international community, Hamas leaders such as{" "} Ismail Haniyeh and Khaled Mashaal struck a tone of cautious pragmatism, expressing openness to political partnership and internal reform. Some, like Mahmoud Zahar, indicated Hamas would maintain its truce if Israel reciprocated. However, other statements made it clear that Hamas would not recognize Israel nor prioritize peace negotiations.

The victory was also aided by Fatah’s internal divisions, as multiple candidates split the party’s vote in many districts. Turnout reached nearly{" "} 78% of 1.3 million eligible voters, demonstrating strong public engagement despite uncertainty and external pressure.

The election marked the first time Hamas contested a parliamentary vote and brought about a seismic shift in Palestinian governance. Critics feared the win could deepen international isolation, while supporters hoped Hamas would bring reform and end internal dysfunction.

title: UN Recognizes Palestine (2012)
description:
On November 29, 2012, the United Nations General Assembly voted to upgrade Palestine’s status to a non-member observer state. The vote passed with an overwhelming 138 in favor, 9 against, and 41 abstentions.

This upgrade was a symbolic but significant diplomatic step. It gave the Palestinians access to various international bodies, including the{" "} International Criminal Court (ICC), and was widely seen as indirect recognition of a Palestinian state within the 1967 borders, including the West Bank, Gaza Strip, and East Jerusalem.

President Mahmoud Abbas told the assembly:{" "} “The General Assembly is called upon today to issue a birth certificate of the reality of the State of Palestine.” He emphasized the move was not meant to delegitimize Israel but to affirm Palestine’s right to statehood.

While Palestinians celebrated across the West Bank and Gaza,{" "} Israel and the United States opposed the resolution, arguing that Palestinian statehood must come through direct negotiations. Israeli Prime Minister{" "} Benjamin Netanyahu called the UN vote “meaningless” and warned it would set back the peace process.

The resolution followed years of stalled peace talks, mainly over Israel’s continued settlement expansion in the West Bank. Many European nations, including France and Italy, supported the resolution, while others remained divided.

The move allowed Palestine to seek membership in more international organizations and pursue legal avenues for statehood. It also reflected global frustration with the lack of progress in negotiations and growing sympathy for the Palestinian cause.

title: Sheikh Jarrah & Gaza Conflict – 2021
description:
In May 2021, violence erupted across Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories in one of the most intense escalations since 2014. The conflict, often referred to as the 2021 Israel–Palestine crisis or the "Unity Intifada", was triggered by Israeli efforts to forcibly evict Palestinian families from the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood in East Jerusalem and Israeli police raids on the al-Aqsa Mosque compound during the final days of Ramadan.

On May 10, 2021, after Israel ignored Hamas's ultimatum to withdraw its forces from Sheikh Jarrah and the al-Aqsa Mosque, Hamas and Islamic Jihad began launching rockets from Gaza into Israeli cities. In response, Israel initiated a massive aerial bombardment campaign across Gaza.

The 11-day war left at least 256 Palestinians dead, including 66 children, and more than 1,900 injured. Israel reported 13 deaths, including 2 children, and hundreds injured. Over 72,000 Palestinians were displaced, and 94 buildings, including media offices and residential towers, were destroyed in Gaza.

The UN and human rights groups condemned Israel's forced evictions and heavy-handed response. The UN OHCHR warned that evictions in Sheikh Jarrah may constitute war crimes. Organizations like B’Tselem and Human Rights Watch described Israel’s dual legal system in East Jerusalem as “apartheid.”

The violence ended with an Egypt-brokered ceasefire on May 21, 2021, though both sides claimed victory. The events of May 2021 sparked widespread protests by Palestinians across Israel, the West Bank, and Gaza, as well as solidarity demonstrations in cities around the world.
